content.description: A conservative force has the potential energy function <math alttext="U of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mi>U</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, indicated by the graph shown. A particle of mass <math alttext="3 kilograms" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> moving in one dimension under the influence of this force has kinetic energy <math alttext="9.5 joules" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> when it is at a position <math alttext="x equals 10 meters" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mtext> m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
